resources.string: Welcome to the Aquarium Information App!!
Use the Bottom Bar to select your desired calculator
Your Valuable Review will be GREATLY Appreciated!! Thank you!!
Would you kindly rate this App?
This app was created by Nick White from North Florida. I am not a programmer, but an enthusiastic aquarist. I went to school for biology and have been in the hobby for over 10 years.

I got tired of having to search for converters every time I wanted to convert meq/L to dKH or determine my new tank’s size. The most commonly used products vary widely in which units are used, and I wanted to create a quick access app to confirm I was dosing the appropriate amount.
Please, inform me of ANY errors. I tried my best to build this app, but I am new to app programming.

-Testing Water Temp is set to 77 °F or 25 °C. Ability to set custom Testing Water Temp is coming! 

-The direct calculation from Salinity (‰ - ppt) to Density (g/l or kg/m3) / Specific Gravity is based on the equation adopted by UNESCO - The One Atmosphere International Equation of the State of Seawater (Millero and Poisson, 1981). 

-The inverse calculation, from Specific Density / Gravity to Salinity, is performed by the solution for iterative methods of the reverse equation of Millero and Poisson. 

-The calculation from Conductivity to Salinity / Density / Gravity Specification is performed according to the complex polynomial equation adopted by UNESCO/ICES/SCOR/IAPSO. In this case,the values are reliable for the resulting salinity between 2 and 42 and a temperature between -2 °C and 35 °C. 

-Salinity values are expressed in Practical Salinity. 

-Thanks to OceanLife.com for providing the source code for the calculations.

This App is more than just a simple Unit Converter: It's tailored more towards Aquarists or anyone interested in water chemistry. 

Not only is there a simple Temperature Converter, but also a Salinity and Alkalinity (KH) converter. 

There’s also a CO₂ calculator for planted aquariums. Also included are Tank Volume Calculators, which will calculate a tank’s volume in gallons or liters and include its water weight. 

There will be more to come including specific aquarium parameters, maintenance plans and more!! If you like this app, please rate it!

Wanting to get new fish but do not know if they will play nicely with what you already have?\nTap Aquarium Fish below to check it out!

Wanting to get new fish but do not know if they will play nicely with what you already have? Just added is a quick reference tool to determine which fish types are compatible with which.\nNOTE:, this feature is in BETA and NON-DEFINITIVE. Mistakes may be present, but I am diligently working on everything!

Mbuna cichlids are a large and diverse group of cichlids endemic to Lake Malawi in East Africa. They are rock-dwelling fish, and they spend most of their time grazing on algae and other plant matter from the rocks. They are also omnivores, and will eat small insects and invertebrates when available. Mbuna cichlids are highly territorial fish, and they can be quite aggressive towards other members of their own species, as well as other fish species.

Tanganyikan cichlids are a diverse group of freshwater fish that are endemic to Lake Tanganyika in East Africa. They are known for their complex social behaviors and their parental care. Many Tanganyikan cichlids are mouthbrooders, meaning that the female incubates the eggs in her mouth until they hatch. Tanganyikan cichlids are also known for their territoriality, and they can be quite aggressive towards other fish, especially those of their own species.

Miscellaneous African cichlids are a diverse group of freshwater fish that are native to Africa. There are over 2,000 species of African cichlids, and they come in a wide variety of shapes, sizes, and colors.

New World cichlids are known for their bright colors and their complex social behaviors. Many New World cichlids are mouthbrooders, meaning that the female incubates the eggs in her mouth until they hatch. New World cichlids can also be quite aggressive, especially towards other members of their own species.

Freshwater angelfish are known for their beautiful appearance, with their tall, pointed fins and their sparkling scales. Angelfish are native to the Amazon River basin in South America. They are found in a variety of habitats, including rivers, streams, and lakes.

Barbs are a diverse group of freshwater fish that are native to Africa, Asia, and Europe. Most barbs are schooling fish, and they do best when kept in groups of at least five or more. However, it is important to note that some barbs can be fin nippers, so they should not be kept with fish with long or delicate fins.

Betta fish, also known as Siamese fighting fish, are small, freshwater fish that are native to Southeast Asia. Betta fish are known for their aggression, especially towards other male betta fish. For this reason, it is best to keep only one male betta fish per aquarium. Female betta fish can be kept together in small groups, but it is important to watch for signs of aggression and separate the fish if necessary.

Cory cats, also known as Corydoras catfish, are known for their peaceful temperament, bottom-dwelling lifestyle, and ability to clean up algae and other debris. Cory cats are typically found in groups in the wild, and they do best when kept in groups in the aquarium as well.

Danio fish are native to South and Southeast Asia. They typically live in streams and rivers with clear, fast-moving water. Danio fish are social animals, and they do best when kept in groups of six or more. They are also relatively peaceful fish, and they can be kept with other fish of similar size and temperament.
Discus fish are a genus of cichlids that are native to the Amazon River basin in South America. They are known for their distinctive disk-shaped body and their bright colors and patterns.
Fancy goldfish are a group of goldfish that have been bred for their unique and ornamental features. Fancy goldfish are also more prone to certain diseases than common goldfish.

Gouramis are a group of freshwater fish that are native to Asia. They are also relatively hardy fish and can tolerate a wide range of water conditions. However, gouramis do require a well-planted aquarium with plenty of hiding places.

Guppies are native to South America and the Caribbean, but have been introduced to many parts of the world. Guppies are livebearers, meaning that they give birth to live young instead of laying eggs. The male guppies are smaller and more brightly colored than the females. Male guppies have long, flowing tails, while females have shorter, more rounded tails. Guppies are social fish and do best when kept in groups of six or more. They can also be kept with other peaceful community fish, such as tetras and platies.

Freshwater hatchet fish are a group of small, colorful fish that are native to South and Central America. They are known for their unique body shape, which resembles a hatchet with large pectoral fins. Hatchet fish are schooling fish, and they prefer to live in groups of six or more.

Freshwater killifish are a group of small, colorful fish that are native to Africa, South America, and Central America. Killifish are known for their short lifespans. Most species live for only one to two years, but some live for as long as four years. Killifish are also known for their ability to go into a dormant state during dry periods. This dormancy allows them to survive droughts and other harsh conditions.

Loaches are a diverse group of bottom-dwelling fish that are found in freshwater habitats all over the world. They are known for their long, slender bodies, small scales, and whisker-like barbels around their mouths. Loaches use their barbels to sift through the sand and mud at the bottom of rivers and lakes in search of food.

Mollies are native to Central and South America, and they can be found in a variety of habitats, including rivers, lakes, and estuaries. They are omnivores and eat a variety of foods, including algae, plants, insects, and small crustaceans. Mollies are a type of freshwater fish that are known for their bright colors and active personalities.

Platies are native to Central America and Mexico, and they come in a wide variety of colors and patterns. Some of the most popular colors include red, orange, yellow, blue, and green. Platies are also known for their unique markings, such as spots, stripes, and marbling.

Plecostomus, also known as plecos, suckermouth catfish, and janitor fish, are a large and diverse group of freshwater fish that are native to South America. They are known for their armored bodies, large sucker mouths, and their ability to eat algae.

Rainbowfish are a group of small, freshwater fish that are native to Australia, New Guinea, and Indonesia. They are known for their bright and colorful scales, which can range in color from blue and green to red and yellow. Rainbowfish are typically between 3 and 6 inches long, and they have a slender body with a forked tail.

Rasboras are a group of small, colorful fish that are native to Southeast Asia. Rasboras are schooling fish, and they prefer to live in groups of six or more. Rasboras are also relatively peaceful fish, and they can be kept with other peaceful fish, such as tetras, guppies, and mollies.
" \"Freshwater sharks\" or simply \"Sharks\", but they are not actually related to sharks. Epalzeorhynchos fish are found in Southeast Asia."

Swordtails are native to Central America, where they inhabit rivers and streams with slow-moving water. Swordtails are named for their sword-shaped lower tail fin, which is present in males. Females have a rounded tail fin.

Tetras are native to South America, Africa, and Central America. Tetras have a long, slender body with a small adipose fin between the dorsal and caudal fins. Tetras are schooling fish, and they need to be kept in groups of at least six individuals. Tetras are also relatively peaceful fish, but they can be aggressive towards smaller fish.

Freshwater aquarium invertebrates are a diverse group of animals that can add interest and beauty to an aquarium. They come in a variety of shapes, sizes, and colors, and they can play an important role in maintaining the health of your aquarium ecosystem.
Snails: Snails are helpful scavengers that can help to keep your aquarium clean by eating algae and detritus. There are many different species of snails to choose from, including mystery snails, nerite snails, and ramshorn snails.
Shrimp: Shrimp are another popular type of freshwater aquarium invertebrate. They are active and peaceful creatures that are easy to care for. There are many different species of shrimp to choose from, including cherry shrimp, amano shrimp, and ghost shrimp.
Crayfish: Crayfish are larger and more aggressive than shrimp, but they can make interesting and unique additions to an aquarium. They are also helpful scavengers that can help to keep your aquarium clean.
Crabs: Crabs are another type of freshwater aquarium invertebrate. They are active and interesting creatures that can make fun additions to an aquarium. However, it is important to note that some crabs can be aggressive towards other fish and invertebrates.

Aquarium brackish fish are fish that can tolerate a wide range of salinities, from freshwater to saltwater. They are typically found in estuaries, where rivers and oceans meet, and in other areas with brackish water, such as mangrove swamps and coastal lagoons.

Koi (鯉, [koꜜi]) are ornamental colored varieties of the common carp (Cyprinus carpio) that are kept for decorative purposes in outdoor koi ponds or water gardens. Koi are a type of domesticated fish that originated in Japan in the 19th century.

Freshwater aquarium plants are a great addition to any freshwater aquarium. They provide many benefits, including:
Improving water quality by absorbing harmful toxins and providing oxygen
Providing hiding places and shelter for fish and other aquatic life
Adding natural beauty and interest to the aquarium

Dwarf angels are found in a variety of reef habitats, and they eat a variety of foods, including algae, sponges, and small invertebrates. Dwarf angels can be a bit territorial, so it is important to choose the right species for your aquarium and to provide them with plenty of hiding places.

" Angels are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world, and they come in a variety of shapes and sizes. They require a large aquarium with plenty of live rock and hiding places. They also need a diet that is rich in algae and other marine invertebrates."

"Anglers, also known as frogfish, are a group of predatory fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their unique appearance, which includes a large, bulbous head and a modified dorsal spine that they use to lure prey. "

Anthias are a group of small, colorful fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their vibrant colors and their schooling behavior. Anthias are typically found in large groups, and they can be very impressive to see swimming together.

Basslets are found in tropical and subtropical waters around the world, and they are often found in deep reefs and lagoons. They are also known to eat small fish and invertebrates. Basslets play an important role in the reef ecosystem by helping to control algae growth and by providing food for other fish.

Batfish (family Ogcocephalidae) are a group of flattened, bottom-dwelling fish that are found in tropical and subtropical oceans around the world. They are known for their unique appearance, with large, flattened heads and wing-like pectoral fins. Batfish are also known for their ability to \"walk\" on the seabed using their pectoral and pelvic fins.

Blennies are a large and diverse group of small fish that are found in marine, freshwater, and brackish habitats all over the world. They are known for their long, slender bodies, large eyes, and brightly colored fins. Blennies are also known for their unique behavior, such as their ability to walk on land and their habit of hiding in crevices and burrows.

Boxfish, also known as cowfish or trunkfish, are a group of brightly colored and uniquely shaped fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are characterized by their rigid, box-like bodies and their hexagonal or \"honeycomb\" patterns on their skin. Boxfish are also known for their strong teeth and their ability to produce a toxic mucus to deter predators.

Butterflyfish are a group of colorful and diverse fish that are found in tropical reefs around the world. They are known for their thin, disk-shaped bodies and their bright, intricate patterns. They are also known to eat parasites from other fish.

Cardinalfish are a group of small, colorful fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their bright colors and their unique behavior. Cardinalfish are often found in pairs or small groups, and they are known to form long-term bonds. They are also known to eat coral polyps and algae.

Chromis fish are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. Chromis is a genus of saltwater fish in the family Pomacentridae, which also includes damselfish and clownfish. Chromis are generally more peaceful than damselfish

Clownfish are small, colorful fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their symbiotic relationship with sea anemones, which they use for protection and shelter. Clownfish have a unique symbiotic relationship with sea anemones. Sea anemones are stinging coral polyps that can provide protection and shelter for clownfish. Clownfish, in turn, help to clean the anemone and protect it from predators.

Damsels are a group of small to medium-sized fish that are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their bright colors and their territorial behavior. Damsels are often found in groups, and they can be very aggressive towards other fish, especially those of their own species.

Dartfish are a group of small, colorful fish that are found in coral reefs around the world. They are known for their unique behavior, which includes swimming in tight formations and performing synchronized dances. Dartfish are also known for their territoriality, and they can be quite aggressive towards other fish, especially those of their own species.

Dragonets, also known as Callionymidae, are a diverse group of small, marine fish that are found mainly in the tropical waters of the Indo-Pacific. They are known for their elongated bodies, large heads, and brightly colored fins. Dragonets are bottom-dwelling fish, and they spend most of their time foraging for food in the sand.

Aquarium eels are all members of the order Anguilliformes, which also includes freshwater eels and moray eels. However, aquarium eels are generally smaller and more peaceful than their wild counterparts.

Filefish are also known as foolfish, leatherjackets, or shingles. They live in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. Filefish are closely related to triggerfish, pufferfish and trunkfish. Filefish are characterized by their rough, sandpapery skin and their large, retractable dorsal spine. The dorsal spine is used for defense, and it can be locked upright to deter predators. Filefish also have a small mouth and a flattened body.
Foxface rabbitfish are typically found in shallow reefs and lagoons in the Indo-Pacific region. They are herbivores, and their diet consists primarily of algae and seagrass.

Gobies are found in all oceans and in many freshwater habitats. Gobies are generally peaceful fish and make good additions to community aquariums. However, some species can be territorial, so it is important to do your research before choosing which gobies to keep together.

Groupers are a large and diverse group of fish that are found in tropical and subtropical oceans around the world. They are known for their large size, stout bodies, and powerful jaws. Groupers are predators, and they feed on a variety of fish, invertebrates, and other marine life.

Grunts are known for their ability to produce a grunting sound by grinding their teeth together. This sound is used to communicate with other grunts, and it can also be used to defend territory or attract mates.
Jawfish are known for their unique behavior of building and maintaining burrows in the sand. Jawfish are also known for their bright colors and their aggressive nature.
Hawkfish are known for their distinctive perch-and-sally behavior, where they perch on a rock or coral head and wait for prey to swim by. Once they see prey, they quickly dart out to capture it.
Hogfish are a family of saltwater fish that are known for their long, pig-like snouts. They are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world.

Lionfish (Pterois volitans and Pterois miles) are marine fish native to the Indo-Pacific region, but have become an invasive species in the Atlantic Ocean. They are known for their beautiful but venomous spines. Lionfish are also voracious predators, and can have a negative impact on native ecosystems.

Parrotfish, also known as Scaridae, are a large and diverse group of fish found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. They are known for their brightly colored bodies and their unique beak-like mouths, which they use to graze on algae and coral polyps. Parrotfish play an important role in the reef ecosystem by helping to control algae growth and by excreting sand, which helps to build and maintain the reefs.

Pseudochromis, also known as dottybacks, are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world. Pseudochromis are generally peaceful fish, but they can be territorial towards other members of their own species.
Puffers are known for their ability to inflate their bodies to avoid being eaten by predators. Pufferfish are also known for their intelligence and their playful personalities.

They are known for their long, slender bodies, prehensile tails, and unusual swimming style. Seahorses are found in tropical and subtropical oceans around the world, while pipefish are found in both freshwater and saltwater habitats.
Aquarium sharks and rays require a large aquarium with plenty of hiding places and a powerful filter. They also need a diet that is high in protein and low in carbohydrates.
Squirrelfish are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world, and they come in a variety of shapes and sizes.
Tangs are a large and diverse group of fish that are popular for their bright colors, active behavior, and algae-eating abilities. Tangs are found in tropical and subtropical reefs around the world.
This information is not definitive or exhaustive.

Triggerfish are a diverse group of marine fish that are known for their aggressive behavior and their distinctive dorsal spine. They are also called balistids, after their scientific name Balistidae. Triggerfish can be found in tropical and subtropical waters around the world. They have a small mouth with strong teeth and a large dorsal spine. The dorsal spine is used to defend themselves from predators and to wedge themselves into crevices.
Many wrasses are beneficial to reef aquariums, as they help to control pests and parasites, but some wrasses can be territorial or aggressive.

Wrasses are a large family of saltwater fish, with over 1,500 species. They are known for their bright colors and diverse body shapes. Wrasses are also very active fish, and they can add a lot of personality to a fish-only aquarium. Wrasses are generally carnivores, and they should be fed a diet of high-quality meaty foods, such as frozen mysis shrimp, brine shrimp, and bloodworms. Some wrasses will also eat algae and other plant matter.
Acroporidae, Faviidae, Zoanthidae, etc.\nAcropora, Favia, Zoanthus, etc.
Aquarium coral provides a number of benefits to aquariums. It helps to filter the water, provides habitat for fish and other marine life, and adds beauty to the aquarium.

Corals: Corals are small, colonial animals that build reefs. They come in a variety of colors and shapes, and can add a lot of visual interest to an aquarium.
Anemones: Anemones are related to corals, but they are solitary animals. They have a central mouth surrounded by stinging tentacles. Anemones can provide a home for clownfish and other fish.
Shrimp: There are many different types of shrimp that can be kept in a marine aquarium. Some shrimp are scavengers, while others are filter feeders. Shrimp can help to keep your aquarium clean and healthy.
Snails: Snails are another type of scavenger that can be kept in a marine aquarium. They can help to remove algae and other detritus from the aquarium.
Crabs: Crabs are another type of scavenger that can be kept in a marine aquarium. They can also help to control algae populations.

This app calculates the volume of water in your aquarium tank and the weight of the water, based on the shape and dimensions of your tank. It also includes temperature, salinity, and alkalinity converters.

Features:
Calculate the volume of water in your aquarium tank for rectangular, cube, cylindrical, hexagonal, and bow-front tanks.
Calculate the weight of the water in your aquarium tank.
Convert temperature, salinity, and alkalinity units.
